introduction.title: Triangle Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Triangle technique is one of the most fundamental designs in flower arrangement. It creates a stable, balanced composition that's pleasing to the eye.
keyPoints: Creates a triangular shape with varying heights
Establishes harmony and balance in arrangements
Works well for formal displays and traditional settings
Often uses odd numbers of flowers for better balance
introduction.history: This technique has roots in Japanese Ikebana and Western classical arrangements. It's considered a foundational skill for all flower arranging.

pages.content: Welcome to the Triangle technique! 💐 This classic design creates stability and harmony in your arrangement. Let's start this exciting journey together!
The triangle technique uses three main points to create a triangular shape. Place your tallest stem at the back center as the apex.
Next, place medium height stems at the sides to form the width of your triangle. These should be slightly shorter than your center stem to create a natural slope.

pages.question: What shape should your arrangement form when using the triangle technique?
options: A perfect circle ⭕
A triangle with the tallest stem in the center 🔺
A square with equal height stems ⬜
A random assortment with no particular shape 🔄
pages.explanation: The triangle technique forms a triangular shape with the tallest stem at the back center (apex) and shorter stems on the sides, creating a three-dimensional triangular form.

pages.content: Now, fill in the remaining spaces with shorter stems and foliage to complete your triangular arrangement. This creates depth, fullness, and visual interest!

pages.question: What is the last step in creating a triangle arrangement?
options: Add more tall stems to the center 🌷
Remove all foliage 🚫
Fill in spaces with shorter stems and foliage 🌿
Create a second triangle upside down 🔻
pages.explanation: The final step is to fill in the spaces with shorter stems and foliage to create depth and fullness in your arrangement, completing the triangular shape.

introduction.title: Auxiliary Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Auxiliary technique focuses on enhancing primary focal flowers with complementary elements that add texture, depth, and visual interest.
keyPoints: Uses supporting flowers and foliage to complement focal blooms
Creates layers of visual interest and texture
Establishes rhythm and movement in arrangements
Adds depth and dimension to flat arrangements
introduction.history: This technique is widely used in European freestyle arrangements and contemporary designs. It emphasizes creativity and personal expression.

pages.content: Welcome to the Auxiliary technique! ✨ This approach focuses on adding supporting elements to enhance your main flowers, creating texture and visual interest.
Begin by placing your focal flowers - these are typically larger, more colorful blooms that draw the eye and serve as the stars of your arrangement.
Now add auxiliary elements like smaller flowers, buds, and textural elements around your focal flowers. These support and enhance the main blooms while adding depth and interest.

pages.question: What is the primary purpose of auxiliary elements in flower arrangement?
options: To replace the main flowers 🔄
To support and enhance the focal flowers ✨
To make the arrangement taller 📏
To reduce the cost of the arrangement 💰
pages.explanation: Auxiliary elements support and enhance the focal flowers by adding texture, depth, and visual interest to the arrangement while allowing the main blooms to shine.

introduction.title: Linear Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Linear technique creates modern, minimalist arrangements with strong directional lines and clean composition.
keyPoints: Emphasizes clean, straight lines and angles
Uses minimal materials for maximum impact
Focuses on negative space as much as the flowers
introduction.history: This approach gained popularity in mid-century modern design and continues to be favored in contemporary and minimalist settings.

pages.content: Welcome to the Linear technique! 📏 This modern approach creates clean, contemporary arrangements with strong lines and minimal elements. Perfect for modern spaces!
Start by selecting long, straight stems like gladiolus, snapdragons, or delphinium. These create the primary lines in your arrangement and establish the overall structure.
Position your stems deliberately to create clear vertical, horizontal, or diagonal lines. The negative space between stems is just as important as the stems themselves.

pages.question: Which of these is a key characteristic of linear arrangements?
options: Full, lush compositions with no visible space between flowers 🌸
Curved, circular placements of stems 🔄
Emphasis on negative space and distinct linear elements ➖
Random, naturalistic placement with no clear direction 🔀
pages.explanation: Linear arrangements emphasize distinct linear elements and the intentional use of negative space to create architectural, contemporary designs.

introduction.title: Foliage Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Foliage technique emphasizes leaves and greenery as primary design elements, creating textural, long-lasting arrangements.
keyPoints: Uses a variety of leaf shapes, sizes, and textures
Creates enduring arrangements with minimal or no flowers
introduction.history: This technique has gained popularity with the rise of sustainable floristry and the shift toward more natural, garden-inspired designs.

pages.content: Welcome to the Foliage technique! 🌿 This approach celebrates the beauty of leaves and greenery as the stars of your arrangement, creating textural impact with minimal or no flowers.
Start by selecting a variety of foliage with different shapes, sizes, and textures. Look for interesting variegation, colors, and leaf forms.
Establish your arrangement's structure with larger, sturdier leaves first. Then add lighter, more delicate foliage for movement and contrast.

pages.question: What is a key benefit of foliage-focused arrangements?
options: They typically last only a day or two 🕐
They require more maintenance than flower arrangements 🔧
They have greater longevity than arrangements relying on flowers 📆
They must include at least 50% flowers to be considered complete 🌼
pages.explanation: Foliage-focused arrangements typically have greater longevity than flower-heavy designs, as leaves and greenery often last much longer than blooms.
